GitHub - gabotechs/dep-tree: allows visualising a "code base entropy" using a 3d force-directed graph of files and the dependencies between them.

Summary to save a click:The dep-tree tool is designed to assist developers in maintaining clean and decoupled code bases. It features the capability to visualize code base entropy through a 3D force-directed graph, which illustrates the files in a project and the dependencies among them. This innovative approach helps in identifying and managing complex dependencies within software projects, promoting better software architecture and easier maintenance.If you don't like the summary, just downvote and I'll try to delete the comment eventually üëçClick here for more info, I read all comments

HTMX and Web Components: a Perfect Match

Key points:The post discusses the synergy between HTMX and Web Components for building interactive web applications without complex frameworks. Web Components allow for creating custom, reusable HTML elements directly in the browser, making them framework-agnostic. HTMX enhances this by enabling any HTML element to make HTTP requests, simplifying the development of SPA-like applications without needing to write JavaScript for data fetching. The article walks through creating such components, configuring them externally for flexibility, and integrating with HTMX for dynamic content loading, showcasing the ease and power of combining these technologies.If you don't like the summary, just downvote and I'll try to delete the comment eventually üëçClick here for more info, I read all comments

Bouncy Ball - Compare Web Animation Techniques

I hope you like the summary below:The link compares different web animation techniques using a bouncy ball animation as an example. It highlights various methods including Vanilla JS, CSS, Canvas, jQuery, GreenSock, and several others, illustrating how each can be used to animate a bouncing ball. The project serves as an educational tool for developers to learn about the strengths and weaknesses of each animation technique, offering a hands-on comparison to help choose the best approach for specific scenarios.If you don't like the summary, just downvote and I'll try to delete the comment eventually üëçClick here for more info, I read all comments

I've read similar stuff about company values. If they all are anodyne words like "integrity" or "caring" they are not values. They are meant to be the backstop rules for conflict resolution.Alice wrote a report. Bob didn't like the findings and tabled it. Alice went over Bob's head and presented her report to Carol. Bob is now mad at Alice and tries to fire her. Alice goes to HR. Who should be fired, Alice or Bob? Depends on what the values are. Well, what does your HR handbook say? What does your company value more, truth/facts/correctness or discipline/order/subordination?

So much text just to say that providing business value is more important than developer's personal experience. Which is a fine point, but it easily gets pushed too far. I'm sure a lot of developers will be happy delivering business value if their respective businesses show any kind of appreciation rather than fighting stress with free pizza.

I'm struggling to promote what I code because I'm coding like 14 hours every day.
If the quality of your systems matches your writing then I fear for your customers

I disagree.And no, I'm not still a little bitter over that time I wrote a perfect query to solve a difficult problem. Literally one of those rare times you stand back and think "Holy cow, I actually wrote... that! I must be better than I thought!" And then two days later they said "oh, we don't need that anymore".

I'm reminded of a video I saw talking about Ringo Starr, the drummer for The Beatles, and how unfairly maligned they are - there are deeper cuts where they demonstrate more advanced technical proficiency, but it's not what the hit songs called for.
Weak or strong just feeds egos. I am here for the money.
Fuck the business, you‚Äôre an artist!

There's no point to being good at something and never being able to put that skill to use though. It would be like having pro baseball skills, and playing tennis instead.EDIT: Delivering value for end-users should be what you're doing with tech skills.
Success stories have no value in terms of information content. It is in the failure stories that we learn.

"Hey guys, refactoring is eating up our budget too much so we cut it to save time! And to hide the real problems and shroud everything in an illusion of progress we cut down stories into tiny little things with 95% overhead and 5% actual development! It totally makes everyone (!!!) happy - EVERYONE - that's why we wrote a blog post about how good it is to ignore what your devs say and toss their happiness to the garbage!"

Technical excellence is what developers are graded on, no? Isn't it the manager's job to provide the customer perspective when the developer is too focused on another thing?Another article which provides another data point that leadership is failing to provide the organization proper directionality so that engineers can make appropriate decisions.

No one dev blog is going to ever solve this because it's a real legitimate trade off where it's impossible to predict the future implications. If I write this faster now and don't plan for x,y,z in advance will we make more money and have a stronger strategic position? It depends on a billion details, how much is having it out now worth, how bad is it in a year if everyone in the company acts this way and now you have a product that you can't iterate on successfully? How likely is that to happen? How costly is just rewriting your product in a year? All of this matters, and people both use this for an excuse to be sloppy, and people use "doing it right" as an excuse to agonize over structural decisions that don't matter and something pointless takes 6 months. Both happen constantly.
A good dev solves the problem at hand while creating minimal negative impact on existing work.A strong dev facilitates and elevates the rest of their team.
Hit 'em with the flex.

I've worked at companies where business is so dominant, they start to wonder why the developers are getting slower and slower and decide to further reduce time to fix those dubious "technical things", if it wasn't already at 0 to begin with. And then I've worked at other companies where I had the simple freedom to fix the technical things, started getting really productive on delivering the stuff business wants, just to encounter some developer who doesn't care about the business side as much and decided to build his camp on hill "Code Review" to show off his never ending skill on nitpicking technical details and re-framing everything as super dramatic, even if it is just opinionated (he viewed it as "technical excellence" but was scared of non-technical tasks). Maybe I should change jobs and go into animal care or something rewarding... thanks for reading until here.
Yes you are.You "lack a sense of urgency".You are being let go.

A new approach to Agile refinement sessions
That‚Äôs great it works for your team. Agile is about agility, so this may not work other places and that is ok. Getting stuff done is what makes software great.

We do a similar thing. We have an informal ‚Äúpre-refinement‚Äù step where tickets of various quality are just pulled towards people (sometimes devs/sometimes the PO) who make sure that all info this ticket references js reachable, that the ticket is concise, that it conforms to our somewhat (intentionally vague) format so it reads easy, and that all people who must contribute something to this ticket in the form of questions, have already answered these questions.Doing that we had a massive increase in work output, better tesability, we spot inconcistensies earlyer. Everyone‚Äôs far more happyer with it. Only adds a couple days at most to a single ticket‚Äôs time between creation and closed, but pays back for it by having less rework or time wasted in the sprint itsself.
Yeah give me more work so I can never write a single line of code. All that is important is that the PO does minimum job

Squeezing Last Bit Of JavaScript Performance For My Automation Game

This is a TL;DR cause time is precious:This post delves into the optimization journey for CivIdle, an automation game that succeeds Industry Idle, focusing on enhancing JavaScript performance. The author explores the transition from using TypeScript/JavaScript to potentially using WebAssembly or C++ for better performance, ultimately sticking with TypeScript for UI and WebGL for rendering due to its efficiency with web platforms. By adopting Pixi.JS for faster WebGL rendering and optimizing code to reduce computation time and resource allocation, significant performance improvements were achieved. Techniques such as object pooling, texture optimization, and code refactoring for efficient memory use were employed. The post highlights challenges and solutions in optimizing game simulation and rendering processes, illustrating the impact of various optimization strategies on game performance.If you don't like the summary, just downvote and I'll try to delete the comment eventually üëçClick here for more info, I read all comments
